posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked:
We have been playing with YAGSL as our third attempt at getting our swerve working consistently but our driver would rather a robot oriented. Is the correct way to get the base code to work as robot oriented instead of field oriented to change the last line in this to drivebase.setDefaultCommand(driveRobotOrientedAngularVelocity)

"    if (RobotBase.isSimulation()) { drivebase.setDefaultCommand(driveFieldOrientedDirectAngleKeyboard); } else { drivebase.setDefaultCommand(driveFieldOrientedAnglularVelocity); } "

Is there anything else necessary. It seems to work for the first motions of the robot but after we turn the wheels once they do not seem to synch back to what the desired motion is showing on advantage scope and eventually end up at 90 degrees to what the original commands were. Ie pressing forward after a while makes the robot go sideways even though the red desired arrows are still saying the desired direction should be forward. Using the new build of the base code with sparks and thrifty encoders. This is the only change other then setting up the json files.
I think that means you need to follow the 8 steps.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked:
Step 1 pressed forward robot shot backwards, press backward it went forwards, pressed side flew into desks

Step 2 pressed forward robot went back pressed back went forward right went left left went right

Step 3 pressed forward robot went in circle

Step 4 Forward went forward back went back, right and left jittered then went on angle then started

Step 5 robot spun

Step 6 Back went forward forward jittered, left and right also went forward and back

Step 7 forward went back then went in circles

Step 8 Forward went forward back went back but left and right would not work then motors were in weird locations and forward and back would not work.

We have checked all wires for the encoders and all do increase when rotated counterclockwise. they all display a consistent value both raw and adjusted and we tried rotating them and the measured states are 0 when forward 90 when rotated sideways counterclockwise, 180 when rotated so gears are to the right, 270 when turned left, and back to 0 when forward with gears to the left. All do register as going forward when rotated by hand. Looking at advantage scope the desired arrows seem to be following the joystick motions but the modules do not seem to want to move to them. Its odd because the movements forward and back work but as soon as we try turning the wheels they seem to move very randomly and dont seem to be trying to get to the setpoints at all just spinning.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked: We have tried p values all the way from the recommended for sparks at 0.02 down to 0.00001 Anything above about a 0.0005 has the modules shake then spin in circles when you remove the joystick input and end at random locations.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Individually check that each device is using the proper coordinate system .  Open up the REV Hardware Client (or whatever tools you have available for your chosen hardware) and unit-test each device.  Don’t drive them through your code, just read their position and manipulate them with your hands.

For each module:

Rotate wheel counter-clockwise (from perspective facing bevel gear) observe positive change in position for drive motor.  If not, invert motor

observe positive change in position for drive motor.  If not, invert motor

rotate modules counter-clockwise (from top-down perspective) observe positive change in position for rotation motor.  If not, invert motor observe positive change for absolute encoder.  If not, invert encoder

observe positive change in position for rotation motor.  If not, invert motor

observe positive change for absolute encoder.  If not, invert encoder

Once done with all 4 modules, rotate entire robot counter-clockwise

observe positive change in gyro angle.  If not, invert gyro.

Note: all “inversions” are based on current state, so it may result in “uninverting”

This process is essentially what the eight steps are guiding you to do, but I find it to be more methodical.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked:
We have done 1 and 2 already and both work.  and done the gyro test all seemed right.

My background is physics not programming so I am trying to understand it from the math. I understand how linear PID works but cannot find the math for exactly how rotation works. How do you calculate the error(i believe that is the term used here for the separation between desired and actual in the PID calculation)  for the turn motor (it seems to be hidden somewhere in the libraries and i cant find it)  Ie does it do degrees/ radians? How does desired angle and actual angle create the PID error in the code? Also if someone could tell me where the variable for the power being sent to the motor is in the yagsl code so i could set up the graphs in smart dashboard for my kids to see what is actually happening with the motors and encoders that would be amazing for me being able to figure it out myself.  The input and desired seem right and the actual is always exactly aligned with the motors in advantagescope but the actual signal the code is sending to the motors does not seem connected to either of those values and knowing what the motor is doing might let me figure it out. (again physicist not programmer or engineer so I have no idea where to look for this information either in the code or the REV apps.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked: My student just figured out how to see the neo info from the spark. The spark encoder does increase when rotated counterclockwise on all modules . I do note that the spark encoder does keep increasing every rotation is there something i need to do to reset it after every rotation?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: They’re likely looking at the “position” value, which uses the built-in relative encoder.  For swerve module rotation, you should have an absolute encoder attached.  If that’s wired to the sensor port on the top of the SparkMax, it should be through the REV Absolute Encoder Adapter board (careful not to confuse it with the similarly named Alternate Encoder Adapter board).  Once there, you should be viewing the absolute encoder position field (I dont remember offhand what the exact name is, so perhaps someone else can grab you a screenshot if you can’t find it).  The absolute encoder position will only return values from 0 to 1 (equivalent to 0-360 degrees), so if graphed, you should see the value wrap around.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Peter_Cudmore:

Also if someone could tell me where the variable for the power being sent to the motor is in the yagsl code so i could set up the graphs in smart dashboard for my kids to see what is actually happening with the motors and encoders that would be amazing for me being able to figure it out myself

YAGSL actually handles dumping most of this data to networktables for you so you can easily monitor things with tools such as AdvantageScope (which comes with the WPILib install if you’ve never used it).  It has a Swerve view that will show the desired and measured states for each module.

posts.name: Peter Cudmore
posts.cooked:
We have thrifty encoders connected to the rio through the analog ports, We do see the angle of the thrifty encoders in the measured states field on advantagescope and the offset does seem to work so that the measures states are all 0 when the wheels are oriented forward with gears left. (picture below of what our advantage scope readouts look like after a motion. When joystick is pressed the desired states do match the joystick input arrows but do sometimes flip back and forth 180 degrees rapidly)
